pullrequest.title: Task 3: Simple collision shapes for crates

content.raw:
That's a good and deep question. The short answer is that shape primitives are in general easier on the physics engine. As far as I understand, it's not a matter of the number of triangles, but also that they're treated as "logical" shapes (i.e. a sphere is the set of points within a certain radius, rather than the triangles which we see on the 3D view).

The main motivation to use them here is that Gazebo suffers from stability issues when there are contacts between trimeshes (non-primitive shapes). Most of Val's body is using trimesh collisions. This means that if one of Val's body parts runs into a wall or object which is also a trimesh, it's likely that things will blow up or get entangled in weird ways.

It should be fine to keep using trimeshes for things which we don't expect Val to interact with, like the rocks outside. On the other hand, it can be oversimplifying if we try to approximate some of the objects with simple shapes, such as the solar panel which Val has to carry. For the objects to be manipulated, we're taking the opposite approach of changing Val's fingers to use simple shapes instead of the objects:

https://gitlab.com/nasa-jsc-robotics/val_description/merge_requests/19
